title: 112_hr4282
content: The International Child Support Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 ensures access to child support services for international child support cases. The Secretary of HHS is authorized to enforce compliance with multilateral child support conventions. This includes access to the Federal Parent Locator Service. The amendment to 42 U.S.C. 653(c) adds a new entity as a Central Authority for child support enforcement in foreign countries. Additionally, the amendment to 42 U.S.C. 654 allows states to require individuals in foreign countries to apply through their country's appropriate Central Authority. The amendment allows states to require individuals in foreign countries to request child support services through the Central Authority in the foreign treaty country. It also amends international support enforcement provisions. The amendment to Section 459A (42 U.S.C. 659a) defines terms like "foreign reciprocating country" and "foreign treaty country" in relation to international child support enforcement. It also references the 2007 Family Maintenance Convention for foreign countries where the convention is in force. The text chunk discusses amendments to various sections related to international child support enforcement, including defining terms like "foreign reciprocating countries" and "foreign treaty countries." It also addresses the collection of past-due support from federal tax refunds and state law requirements concerning the Uniform Interstate Family. Amendments are made to Section 466(f) and Section 1738B of title 28, United States Code, regarding the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA). The changes include updating the adoption date to September 30, 2008, and allowing the state tribunal to continue jurisdiction to modify orders with consent from the parties. Amendments to Section 466(f) and Section 1738B of title 28, United States Code under the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) allow the state tribunal to retain jurisdiction to modify orders if parties consent. Amendments to the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) allow state tribunals to modify orders with parties' consent. The term definitions in the Act have been revised to clarify key terms such as 'child support,' 'child support order,' 'contestant,' 'court,' 'modification,' and 'State.' The amendments to the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) include a definition of the term 'State' and specify the effective date for state law changes, allowing modifications with parties' consent. The amendments to the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) specify that each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature. The effective dates for the amendments depend on the enactment of the Hague Convention and the date of the Act. DATA EXCHANGE STANDARDIZATION FOR IMPROVED INTEROPERABILITY. The Secretary, in consultation with an interagency work group, shall designate nonproprietary and interoperable data exchange standards for information reporting. The Secretary shall designate nonproprietary and interoperable data exchange standards, incorporating standards from international bodies and intergovernmental partnerships. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant Federal entities, shall designate data exchange standards for reporting, considering State and tribal perspectives. These standards should incorporate widely-accepted interoperable standards and be nonproprietary. The Secretary shall designate data exchange standards for reporting, incorporating nonproprietary, searchable, computer-readable formats consistent with accounting principles and capable of continual upgrades. Nonproprietary standards like the eXtensible Markup Language should be included. Effective dates for these standards will be determined by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Human Services will issue a proposed rule within 12 months and a final rule within 24 months under section 452(o)(1) of the Social Security Act. Data reporting standards under section 452(o)(2) will be effective for reports in the first reporting period after the final rule is established. Efficient use of the National Directory of New Hires database for federally sponsored research to assess federal policies' effectiveness in achieving positive labor market outcomes. Section 453 (42 U.S.C. 653) is amended to allow the Secretary to provide access to data for research purposes by State or Federal agencies, including information reported by employers. The Secretary can provide access to data for research purposes by State or Federal agencies, including evaluations or statistical analysis to assess the effectiveness of Federal programs in achieving positive labor market outcomes. This includes agencies such as the Department of Health and Human Services, Social Security Administration, Department of Labor, Department of Education, Department of Housing and Urban Development, and Department of Justice. The Secretary can provide data for research purposes to State or Federal agencies like the Department of Justice, Department of Veterans Affairs, Bureau of the Census, Department of Agriculture, or National Science Foundation. Personal identifiers can be included if certain requirements are met. The Secretary can provide data to agencies for evaluation or statistical analysis under an agreement ensuring data security and use restrictions. The Secretary can provide data for research purposes under certain conditions to ensure data security and prevent unauthorized disclosure. Penalties are in place for individuals who disclose personal identifiers without authorization. The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The statement must be submitted before the vote on passage.
